class="reference" id="cite_ref-47">\n        <a href="#cite_note-47">\n         [46]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-etymology_48-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-etymology-48">\n         [47]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WChafe_49-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-WChafe-49">\n         [48]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Whether a Native American tribe was friendly or warlike was critical to the fates of European explorers and\n       <a href="/wiki/Settler" title="Settler">\n        settlers\n       </a>\n       in that land.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50">\n        <a href="#cite_note-50">\n         [49]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Friendly tribes taught newcomers how to grow indigenous crops, prepare foods, and hunt\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Game_(food)" title="Game (food)">\n        wild game\n       </a>\n       . Warlike tribes made life difficult and dangerous for Europeans through their attacks and resistance to the newcomers.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51">\n        <a href="#cite_note-51">\n         [50]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h3>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Colonization">\n        Colonization\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Main articles:\n       <a href="/wiki/French_colonization_of_Texas" title="French colonization of Texas">\n        French colonization of Texas\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Texas" title="Spanish Texas">\n        Spanish Texas\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Texas" title="Mexican Texas">\n        Mexican Texas\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Six_Flags_over_Texas.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2328" data-file-width="3259" height="186" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Six_Flags_over_Texas.jpg/260px-Six_Flags_over_Texas.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Six_Flags_over_Texas.jpg/390px-Six_Flags_over_Texas.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Six_Flags_over_Texas.jpg/520px-Six_Flags_over_Texas.jpg 2x" width="260"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Six_Flags_over_Texas.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         Flags of the\n         <a href="/wiki/Six_flags_over_Texas" title="Six flags over Texas">\n          six nations\n         </a>\n         that have had sovereignty over some or all of the current territory of Texas\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       The first historical document related to Texas was a map of the\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gulf_Coast" title="Gulf Coast">\n        Gulf Coast\n       </a>\n       , created in 1519 by Spanish explorer\n       <a href="/wiki/Alonso_%C3%81lvarez_de_Pineda" title="Alonso \xc3\x81lvarez de Pineda">\n        Alonso \xc3\x81lvarez de Pineda\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chipman243_52-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-chipman243-52">\n         [51]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-weber34_53-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-weber34-53">\n         [52]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Nine years later, shipwrecked Spanish explorer\n       <a href="/wiki/%C3%81lvar_N%C3%BA%C3%B1ez_Cabeza_de_Vaca" title="\xc3\x81lvar N\xc3\xba\xc3\xb1ez Cabeza de Vaca">\n        \xc3\x81lvar N\xc3\xba\xc3\xb1ez Cabeza de Vaca\n       </a>\n       and his cohort became the first Europeans in what is now Texas.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CVaca_54-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-CVaca-54">\n         [53]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SpanishT_55-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-SpanishT-55">\n         [54]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Cabeza de Vaca reported that in 1528, when the Spanish landed in the area, "half the natives died from a disease of the bowels and blamed us."\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56">\n        <a href="#cite_note-56">\n         [55]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Cabeza de Vaca also made observations about the way of life of the Ignaces Natives of Texas: "They went about with a firebrand, setting fire to the plains and timber so as to drive off the mosquitos, and also to get lizards and similar things which they eat, to come out of the soil. In the same manner they kill deer, encircling them with fires, and they do it also to deprive the animals of pasture, compelling them to go for food where the Indians want."\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57">\n        <a href="#cite_note-57">\n         [56]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       <a href="/wiki/Francisco_V%C3%A1zquez_de_Coronado" title="Francisco V\xc3\xa1zquez de Coronado">\n        Francisco V\xc3\xa1zquez de Coronado\n       </a>\n       describes his 1541 encounter with "Two kinds of people travel around these plains with the cows; one is called\n       <a href="/wiki/Querecho_Indians" title="Querecho Indians">\n        Querechos\n       </a>\n       and the others\n       <a href="/wiki/Teyas_Indians" title="Teyas Indians">\n        Teyas\n       </a>\n       ; they are very well built, and painted, and are enemies of each other. They have no other settlement or location than comes from traveling around with the cows. They kill all of these they wish, and tan the hides, with which they clothe themselves and make their tents, and they eat the flesh, sometimes even raw, and they also even drink the blood when thirsty. The tents they make are like field tents, and they set them up over some poles they have made for this purpose, which come together and are tied at the top, and when they go from one place to another they carry them on some dogs they have, of which they have many, and they load them with the tents and poles and other things, for the country is so level, as I said, that they can make use of these, because they carry the poles dragging along on the ground. The sun is what they worship most."\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58">\n        <a href="#cite_note-58">\n         [57]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       European powers ignored the area until accidentally settling there in 1685. Miscalculations by\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ren%C3%A9-Robert_Cavelier_de_La_Salle" title="Ren\xc3\xa9-Robert Cavelier de La Salle">\n        Ren\xc3\xa9-Robert Cavelier de La Salle\n       </a>\n       resulted in his establishing the colony of\n       <a href="/wiki/French_colonization_of_Texas" title="French colonization of Texas">\n        Fort Saint Louis\n       </a>\n       at\n       <a href="/wiki/Matagorda_Bay" title="Matagorda Bay">\n        Matagorda Bay\n       </a>\n       rather than along the\n       <a href="/wiki/Mississippi_River" title="Mississippi River">\n        Mississippi River\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-weber149_59-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-weber149-59">\n         [58]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The colony lasted only four years before succumbing to harsh conditions and hostile natives.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chipman83_60-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-chipman83-60">\n         [59]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <div class="thumb tleft">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_Texas_1718.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1453" height="198" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Map_of_Texas_1718.jpg/240px-Map_of_Texas_1718.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Map_of_Texas_1718.jpg/360px-Map_of_Texas_1718.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Map_of_Texas_1718.jpg/480px-Map_of_Texas_1718.jpg 2x" width="240"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_Texas_1718.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         A 1718 map of Texas by\n         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Guillaume_de_L%27Isle" title="Guillaume de L\'Isle">\n          Guillaume de L\'Isle\n         </a>\n         . Approximate state area highlighted, northern areas indefinite.\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       In 1690 Spanish authorities, concerned that France posed competitive threat, constructed several\n       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_missions_in_Texas" title="Spanish missions in Texas">\n        missions\n       </a>\n       in\n       <a href="/wiki/East_Texas" title="East Texas">\n        East Texas\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chipman89_61-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-chipman89-61">\n         [60]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       After Native American resistance, the Spanish missionaries returned to Mexico.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-weber155_62-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-weber155-62">\n         [61]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       When France began settling\n       <a href="/wiki/Louisiana_(New_France)" title="Louisiana (New France)">\n        Louisiana\n       </a>\n       , mostly in the southern part of the state, in 1716 Spanish authorities responded by founding a new series of missions in East Texas.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chipman111and2_63-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-chipman111and2-63">\n         [62]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-weber160_64-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-weber160-64">\n         [63]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Two years later, they created\n       <a href="/wiki/San_Antonio" title="San Antonio">\n        San Antonio\n       </a>\n       as the first Spanish civilian settlement in the area.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-weber163_65-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-weber163-65">\n         [64]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:LaFora_1771_2.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="512" data-file-width="821" height="181" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/LaFora_1771_2.jpg/290px-LaFora_1771_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/LaFora_1771_2.jpg/435px-LaFora_1771_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/LaFora_1771_2.jpg/580px-LaFora_1771_2.jpg 2x" width="290"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:LaFora_1771_2.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         Nicolas de La Fora\'s 1771 map of the northern frontier of New Spain clearly shows the Provincia de los Tejas.\n         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66">\n          <a href="#cite_note-66">\n           [65]\n          </a>\n         </sup>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       Hostile native tribes and distance from nearby Spanish colonies discouraged settlers from moving to the area. It was one of New Spain\'s least populated provinces.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chipman205_67-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-chipman205-67">\n         [66]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       In 1749, the Spanish peace treaty with the\n       <a href="/wiki/Lipan_Apache_people" title="Lipan Apache people">\n        Lipan Apache\n       </a>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-weber193_68-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-weber193-68">\n         [67]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       angered many tribes, including the\n       <a href="/wiki/Comanche" title="Comanche">\n        Comanche\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Tonkawa" title="Tonkawa">\n        Tonkawa\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Hasinai" title="Hasinai">\n        Hasinai\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-weber189_69-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-weber189-69">\n         [68]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The Comanche signed a treaty with Spain in 1785\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-weddle163_70-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-weddle163-70">\n         [69]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       and later helped to defeat the Lipan Apache and\n       <a href="/wiki/Karankawa_people" title="Karankawa people">\n        Karankawa\n       </a>\n       tribes.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-weddle164_71-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-weddle164-71">\n         [70]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chipman200_72-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-chipman200-72">\n         [71]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       With more numerous missions being established, priests led a peaceful conversion of most tribes. By the end of the 18th century only a few\n       <a href="/wiki/Nomad" title="Nomad">\n        nomadic\n       </a>\n       tribes had not converted to Christianity.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chipman202_73-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-chipman202-73">\n         [72]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <div class="thumb tleft">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Stephen_f_austin.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1207" data-file-width="1016" height="214" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Stephen_f_austin.jpg/180px-Stephen_f_austin.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Stephen_f_austin.jpg/270px-Stephen_f_austin.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Stephen_f_austin.jpg/360px-Stephen_f_austin.jpg 2x" width="180"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Stephen_f_austin.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         <a href="/wiki/Stephen_F._Austin" title="Stephen F. Austin">\n          Stephen F. Austin\n         </a>\n         was the first American\n         <i>\n          <a href="/wiki/Empresario" title="Empresario">\n           empresario\n          </a>\n         </i>\n         given permission to operate a colony within\n         <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Texas" title="Mexican Texas">\n          Mexican Texas\n         </a>\n         .\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mexico_1824_(equirectangular_projection).png">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1047" data-file-width="1400" height="217" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Mexico_1824_%28equirectangular_projection%29.png/290px-Mexico_1824_%28equirectangular_projection%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Mexico_1824_%28equirectangular_projection%29.png/435px-Mexico_1824_%28equirectangular_projection%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Mexico_1824_%28equirectangular_projection%29.png/580px-Mexico_1824_%28equirectangular_projection%29.png 2x" width="290"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mexico_1824_(equirectangular_projection).png" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         Mexico in 1824.\n         <a href="/wiki/Coahuila_y_Tejas" title="Coahuila y Tejas">\n          Coahuila y Tejas\n         </a>\n         is the northeastern-most state.\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       When the United States\n       <a href="/wiki/Louisiana_Purchase" title="Louisiana Purchase">\n        purchased Louisiana\n       </a>\n       from France in 1803, American authorities insisted that the agreement also included Texas. The boundary between New Spain and the United States was finally set at the\n       <a href="/wiki/Sabine_River_(Texas%E2%80%93Louisiana)" title="Sabine River (Texas\xe2\x80\x93Louisiana)">\n        Sabine River\n       </a>\n       in 1819, at what is now the border between Texas and Louisiana.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-weber291to9_74-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-weber291to9-74">\n         [73]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Eager for new land, many United States settlers refused to recognize the agreement. Several\n       <a href="/wiki/Filibuster_(military)" title="Filibuster (military)">\n        filibusters\n       </a>\n       raised armies to invade the area west of the Sabine River.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-davis46_75-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-davis46-75">\n         [74]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       In 1821, the\n       <a href="/wiki/Mexican_War_of_Independence" title="Mexican War of Independence">\n        Mexican War of Independence\n       </a>\n       included the Texas territory, which became part of Mexico.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-weber300_76-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-weber300-76">\n         [75]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Due to its low population, Mexico made the area part of the state of\n       <a href="/wiki/Coahuila_y_Tejas" title="Coahuila y Tejas">\n        Coahuila y Tejas\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-manchaca162_77-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-manchaca162-77">\n         [76]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Hoping that more settlers would reduce the near-constant Comanche raids,\n       <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Texas" title="Mexican Texas">\n        Mexican Texas\n       </a>\n       liberalized its immigration policies to permit immigrants from outside Mexico and Spain.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-manchaca164_78-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-manchaca164-78">\n         [77]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Under the Mexican immigration system, large swathes of land were allotted to\n       <i>\n        <a href="/wiki/Empresario" title="Empresario">\n         empresarios\n        </a>\n       </i>\n       , who recruited settlers from the United States, Europe, and the Mexican interior. The first grant, to\n       <a href="/wiki/Moses_Austin" title="Moses Austin">\n        Moses Austin\n       </a>\n       , was passed to his son\n       <a href="/wiki/Stephen_F._Austin" title="Stephen F. Austin">\n        Stephen F. Austin\n       </a>\n       after his death.\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Austin\'s settlers, the\n       <a href="/wiki/Old_Three_Hundred" title="Old Three Hundred">\n        Old Three Hundred\n       </a>\n       , made places along the\n       <a href="/wiki/Brazos_River" title="Brazos River">\n        Brazos River\n       </a>\n       in 1822.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-manchaca198_79-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-manchaca198-79">\n         [78]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Twenty-three other empresarios brought settlers to the state, the majority of whom were from the United States.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-manchaca198_79-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-manchaca198-79">\n         [78]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80">\n        <a href="#cite_note-80">\n         [79]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The population of Texas grew rapidly. In 1825, Texas had about 3,500 people, with most of Mexican descent.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-edmondson75_81-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-edmondson75-81">\n         [80]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       By 1834, the population had grown to about 37,800 people, with only 7,800 of Mexican descent.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-manchaca201and172_82-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-manchaca201and172-82">\n         [81]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Most of these early settlers who arrived with Austin and soon after were persons less than fortunate in life, as Texas was devoid of the comforts found elsewhere in Mexico and the United States during that time period. Early Texas settler David B. Edwards described his fellow Texans as being "banished from the pleasures of life."\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83">\n        <a href="#cite_note-83">\n         [82]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Many immigrants openly flouted Mexican law, especially the prohibition against\n       <a href="/wiki/Slavery" title="Slavery">\n        slavery\n       </a>\n       . Combined with United States\' attempts to purchase Texas, Mexican authorities decided in 1830 to prohibit continued immigration from the United States.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-edmondson78_84-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-edmondson78-84">\n         [83]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       New laws also called for the enforcement of\n       <a href="/wiki/Duty_(economics)" title="Duty (economics)">\n        customs duties\n       </a>\n       angering both native Mexican citizens (\n       <i>\n        <a href="/wiki/Tejano" title="Tejano">\n         Tejanos\n        </a>\n       </i>\n       ) and recent immigrants.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-davis77_85-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-davis77-85">\n         [84]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The\n       <a href="/wiki/Anahuac_Disturbances" title="Anahuac Disturbances">\n        Anahuac Disturbances\n       </a>\n       in 1832 were the first open revolt against Mexican rule and they coincided with a revolt in Mexico against the nation\'s president.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-davis85_86-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-davis85-86">\n         [85]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Texian" title="Texian">\n        Texians\n       </a>\n       sided with the\n       <a href="/wiki/Federalism" title="Federalism">\n        federalists\n       </a>\n       against the current government and drove all Mexican soldiers out of East Texas.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-davis86to89_87-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-davis86to89-87">\n         [86]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       They took advantage of the lack of oversight to agitate for more political freedom. Texians met at the\n       <a href="/wiki/Convention_of_1832" title="Convention of 1832">\n        Convention of 1832\n       </a>\n       to discuss requesting independent statehood, among other issues.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-davis92_88-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-davis92-88">\n         [87]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The following year, Texians reiterated their demands at the\n       <a href="/wiki/Convention_of_1833" title="Convention of 1833">\n        Convention of 1833\n       </a>\n       .\n      </p>\n      <h3>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Republic">\n        Republic\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Main articles:\n       <a href="/wiki/Texas_Revolution" title="Texas Revolution">\n        Texas Revolution\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Texas" title="Republic of Texas">\n        Republic of Texas\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       Within Mexico, tensions continued between federalists and centralists. In early 1835, wary\n       <a href="/wiki/Texians" title="Texians">\n        Texians\n       </a>\n       formed Committees of Correspondence and Safety.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-huson4_89-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-huson4-89">\n         [88]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The unrest erupted into armed conflict in late 1835 at the\n       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Gonzales" title="Battle of Gonzales">\n        Battle of Gonzales\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hardin12_90-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-hardin12-90">\n         [89]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       This launched the\n       <a href="/wiki/Texas_Revolution" title="Texas Revolution">\n        Texas Revolution\n       </a>\n       , and over the next two months, the Texians defeated all Mexican troops in the region.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-barr64_91-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-barr64-91">\n         [90]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Texians elected delegates to the\n       <a href="/wiki/Consultation_(Texas)" title="Consultation (Texas)">\n        Consultation\n       </a>\n       , which created a provisional government.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-winders72_92-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-winders72-92">\n         [91]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The provisional government soon collapsed from infighting, and Texas was without clear governance for the first two months of 1836.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-winders90and92_93-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-winders90and92-93">\n         [92]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hardin109_94-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-hardin109-94">\n         [93]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <div class="thumb tleft">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:332px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:SantaAnnaSurrender.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="587" data-file-width="1024" height="189" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/SantaAnnaSurrender.jpg/330px-SantaAnnaSurrender.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/SantaAnnaSurrender.jpg/495px-SantaAnnaSurrender.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/SantaAnnaSurrender.jpg/660px-SantaAnnaSurrender.jpg 2x" width="330"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:SantaAnnaSurrender.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         William Henry Huddle:\n         <i>\n          Surrender of Santa Anna\n         </i>\n         (1886;\n         <a href="/wiki/Texas_State_Capitol" title="Texas State Capitol">\n          Texas State Capitol\n         </a>\n         ,\n         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Austin" title="Austin">\n          Austin\n         </a>\n         )\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       During this time of political turmoil, Mexican President\n       <a href="/wiki/Antonio_L%C3%B3pez_de_Santa_Anna" title="Antonio L\xc3\xb3pez de Santa Anna">\n        Antonio L\xc3\xb3pez de Santa Anna\n       </a>\n       personally led an army to end the revolt.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hardin102_95-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-hardin102-95">\n         [94]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The Mexican expedition was initially successful. General\n       <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_de_Urrea" title="Jos\xc3\xa9 de Urrea">\n        Jos\xc3\xa9 de Urrea\n       </a>\n       defeated all the Texian resistance along the coast culminating in the\n       <a href="/wiki/Goliad_massacre" title="Goliad massacre">\n        Goliad massacre\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Handbook_96-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Handbook-96">\n         [95]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Santa Anna\'s forces, after a\n       <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_the_Alamo" title="Siege of the Alamo">\n        thirteen-day siege\n       </a>\n       , overwhelmed Texian defenders at the\n       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Alamo" title="Battle of the Alamo">\n        Battle of the Alamo\n       </a>\n       . News of the defeats sparked panic amongst Texas settlers.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-todish68_97-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-todish68-97">\n         [96]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wpdms_republic_of_texas.svg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="410" data-file-width="333" height="271" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Wpdms_republic_of_texas.svg/220px-Wpdms_republic_of_texas.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Wpdms_republic_of_texas.svg/330px-Wpdms_republic_of_texas.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Wpdms_republic_of_texas.svg/440px-Wpdms_republic_of_texas.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Wpdms_republic_of_texas.svg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         The present-day outlines of the U.S. states superimposed on the boundaries of the 1836\xe2\x80\x931845\n         <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Texas" title="Republic of Texas">\n          Republic of Texas\n         </a>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       The newly elected Texian delegates to the\n       <a href="/wiki/Convention_of_1836" title="Convention of 1836">\n        Convention of 1836\n       </a>\n       quickly signed a\n       <a href="/wiki/Texas_Declaration_of_Independence" title="Texas Declaration of Independence">\n        Declaration of Independence\n       </a>\n       on March 2, forming the\n       <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Texas" title="Republic of Texas">\n        Republic of Texas\n       </a>\n       . After electing interim officers, the Convention disbanded.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-roberts144_98-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-roberts144-98">\n         [97]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The new government joined the other settlers in Texas in the\n       <a href="/wiki/Runaway_Scrape" title="Runaway Scrape">\n        Runaway Scrape\n       </a>\n       , fleeing from the approaching Mexican army.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-todish68_97-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-todish68-97">\n         [96]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       After several weeks of retreat, the\n       <a href="/wiki/Texian_Army" title="Texian Army">\n        Texian Army\n       </a>\n       commanded by\n       <a href="/wiki/Sam_Houston" title="Sam Houston">\n        Sam Houston\n       </a>\n       attacked and defeated Santa Anna\'s forces at the\n       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_San_Jacinto" title="Battle of San Jacinto">\n        Battle of San Jacinto\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-todish69_99-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-todish69-99">\n         [98]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Santa Anna was captured and forced to sign the\n       <a href="/wiki/Treaties_of_Velasco" title="Treaties of Velasco">\n        Treaties of Velasco\n       </a>\n       , ending the war.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-todish70_100-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-todish70-100">\n         [99]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       While Texas had won its independence, political battles raged between two factions of the new Republic. The nationalist faction, led by\n       <a href="/wiki/Mirabeau_B._Lamar" title="Mirabeau B. Lamar">\n        Mirabeau B. Lamar\n       </a>\n       , advocated the continued independence of Texas, the expulsion of the Native Americans, and the expansion of the Republic to the Pacific Ocean. Their opponents, led by Sam Houston, advocated the annexation of Texas to the United States and peaceful co-existence with Native Americans. The conflict between the factions was typified by an incident known as the\n       <a href="/wiki/Texas_Archive_War" title="Texas Archive War">\n        Texas Archive War\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-archivewar_101-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-archivewar-101">\n         [100]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Mexico launched two small expeditions into Texas in 1842. The town of San Antonio was captured twice and Texans were defeated in battle in the\n       <a href="/wiki/Dawson_massacre" title="Dawson massacre">\n        Dawson massacre\n       </a>\n       . Despite these successes, Mexico did not keep an occupying force in Texas, and the republic survived.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Calvert_102-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Calvert-102">\n         [101]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The republic\'s inability to defend itself added momentum to Texas\'s eventual annexation into the United States.\n      </p>\n      <h3>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Statehood">\n        Statehood\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Main articles:\n       <a href="/wiki/Texas_annexation" title="Texas annexation">\n        Texas annexation\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Mexican%E2%80%93American_War" title="Mexican\xe2\x80\x93American War">\n        Mexican\xe2\x80\x93American War\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       As early as 1837, the Republic made several attempts to negotiate\n       <a href="/wiki/Annexation" title="Annexation">\n        annexation\n       </a>\n       with the United States.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103">\n        <a href="#cite_note-103">\n         [102]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Opposition within the republic from the nationalist faction, along with strong\n       <a href="/wiki/Abolitionism_in_the_United_States" title="Abolitionism in the United States">\n        abolitionist\n       </a>\n       opposition within the United States, slowed Texas\'s admission into the Union. Texas was finally\n       <a href="/wiki/Texas_annexation" title="Texas annexation">\n        annexed\n       </a>\n       when the expansionist\n       <a href="/wiki/James_K._Polk" title="James K. Polk">\n        James K. Polk\n       </a>\n       won the\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1844" title="United States presidential election, 1844">\n        election of 1844\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104">\n        <a href="#cite_note-104">\n         [103]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       On December 29, 1845,\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Congress" title="United States Congress">\n        Congress\n       </a>\n       admitted Texas to the U.S. as a constituent state of the Union.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TAnnexation_105-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-TAnnexation-105">\n         [104]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The population of the new state was quite small at first and there was a strong mix between the English-speaking American settlers that dominated in the eastern/northeastern portions of the state and the Spanish-speaking former Mexicans that dominated in the southern and western portions of the state. Statehood brought many new settlers. Because of the long Spanish presence in Mexico and various failed colonization efforts by the Spanish and Mexicans in northern Mexico, there were large herds of\n       <a href="/wiki/Texas_Longhorn" title="Texas Longhorn">\n        Longhorn cattle\n       </a>\n       that roamed the state. Hardy by nature but also suitable for slaughtering and consumption, they represented an economic opportunity that many entrepreneurs seized upon, thus creating the cowboy culture for which Texas is famous. While in the early days of the republic cattle and bison were slaughtered for their hides, soon a beef industry was established with cattle being shipped all over the U.S. and the Caribbean (within a few decades, beef had become a staple of the American diet).\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       After Texas\'s annexation, Mexico broke diplomatic relations with the United States. While the United States claimed that Texas\'s border stretched to the Rio Grande, Mexico claimed it was the\n       <a href="/wiki/Nueces_River" title="Nueces River">\n        Nueces River\n       </a>\n       . While the former Republic of Texas could not enforce its border claims, the United States had the military strength and the political will to do so. President Polk ordered General\n       <a href="/wiki/Zachary_Taylor" title="Zachary Taylor">\n        Zachary Taylor\n       </a>\n       south to the Rio Grande on January 13, 1846. A few months later Mexican troops routed an American cavalry patrol in the disputed area in the\n       <a href="/wiki/Thornton_Affair" title="Thornton Affair">\n        Thornton Affair\n       </a>\n       starting the\n       <a href="/wiki/Mexican%E2%80%93American_War" title="Mexican\xe2\x80\x93American War">\n        Mexican\xe2\x80\x93American War\n       </a>\n       . The first battles of the war were fought in Texas: the\n       <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Fort_Texas" title="Siege of Fort Texas">\n        Siege of Fort Texas\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Palo_Alto" title="Battle of Palo Alto">\n        Battle of Palo Alto\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Resaca_de_la_Palma" title="Battle of Resaca de la Palma">\n        Battle of Resaca de la Palma\n       </a>\n       . After these decisive victories, the United States invaded Mexican territory ending the fighting in Texas.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mwar_106-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Mwar-106">\n         [105]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Texas_proposed_boundaries.svg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1425" data-file-width="1475" height="164" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Texas_proposed_boundaries.svg/170px-Texas_proposed_boundaries.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Texas_proposed_boundaries.svg/255px-Texas_proposed_boundaries.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Texas_proposed_boundaries.svg/340px-Texas_proposed_boundaries.svg.png 2x" width="170"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Texas_proposed_boundaries.svg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         Proposals of 1850 for Texas northwestern boundary\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       After a series of United States victories, the\n       <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Guadalupe_Hidalgo" title="Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo">\n        Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo\n       </a>\n       ended the two-year war. In return, for US$18,250,000, Mexico gave the U.S. undisputed control of Texas, ceded the\n       <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Cession" title="Mexican Cession">\n        Mexican Cession\n       </a>\n       in 1848, most of which today is called the American Southwest, and Texas\'s borders were established at the Rio Grande.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mwar_106-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Mwar-106">\n         [105]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The\n       <a href="/wiki/Compromise_of_1850" title="Compromise of 1850">\n        Compromise of 1850\n       </a>\n       set Texas\'s boundaries at their present form. U.S. Senator\n       <a href="/wiki/James_Pearce" title="James Pearce">\n        James Pearce\n       </a>\n       of Maryland drafted the final proposal\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-comp1850_19-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-comp1850-19">\n         [18]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       where Texas ceded its claims to land which later became half of present-day\n       <a href="/wiki/New_Mexico" title="New Mexico">\n        New Mexico\n       </a>\n       , a third of\n       <a href="/wiki/Colorado" title="Colorado">\n        Colorado\n       </a>\n       , and small portions of\n       <a href="/wiki/Kansas" title="Kansas">\n        Kansas\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Oklahoma" title="Oklahoma">\n        Oklahoma\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Wyoming" title="Wyoming">\n        Wyoming\n       </a>\n       to the federal government, in return for the assumption of $10 million of the old republic\'s debt.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-comp1850_19-2">\n        <a href="#cite_note-comp1850-19">\n         [18]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Post-war Texas grew rapidly as migrants poured into the cotton lands of the state.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CCulture_107-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-CCulture-107">\n         [106]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       They also brought or purchased enslaved African Americans, whose numbers tripled in the state from 1850 to 1860, from 58,000 to 182,566.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108">\n        <a href="#cite_note-108">\n         [107]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h3>\n       <span id="Civil_War_and_Reconstruction_(1860\xe2\x80\x931900)">\n       </span>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Civil_War_and_Reconstruction_.281860.E2.80.931900.29">\n        Civil War and Reconstruction (1860\xe2\x80\x931900)\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Main article:\n       <a href="/wiki/Texas_in_the_American_Civil_War" title="Texas in the American Civil War">\n        Texas in the American Civil War\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Glory_to_the_defeated_-_dignified_resignation.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3072" data-file-width="1908" height="274" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Glory_to_the_defeated_-_dignified_resignation.jpg/170px-Glory_to_the_defeated_-_dignified_resignation.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Glory_to_the_defeated_-_dignified_resignation.jpg/255px-Glory_to_the_defeated_-_dignified_resignation.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Glory_to_the_defeated_-_dignified_resignation.jpg/340px-Glory_to_the_defeated_-_dignified_resignation.jpg 2x" width="170"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Glory_to_the_defeated_-_dignified_resignation.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         Civil war monument in\n         <a href="/wiki/Galveston,_Texas" title="Galveston, Texas">\n          Galveston, Texas\n         </a>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       Texas was at war again after the\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1860" title="United States presidential election, 1860">\n        election of 1860\n       </a>\n       . At this time, blacks comprised 30 percent of the state\'s population, and they were overwhelmingly enslaved.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HTO_109-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-HTO-109">\n         [108]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       When\n       <a href="/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln" title="Abraham Lincoln">\n        Abraham Lincoln\n       </a>\n       was elected, South Carolina seceded from the Union. Five other\n       <a href="/wiki/Deep_South" title="Deep South">\n        Lower South states\n       </a>\n       quickly followed. A State Convention considering secession opened in Austin on January 28, 1861. On February 1, by a vote of 166\xe2\x80\x938, the Convention adopted an\n       <a href="/wiki/Ordinance_of_Secession" title="Ordinance of Secession">\n        Ordinance of Secession\n       </a>\n       from the United States. Texas voters approved this Ordinance on February 23, 1861. Texas joined the newly created Confederate States of America on March 4, 1861 ratifying the permanent\n       <a href="/wiki/Confederate_States_Constitution" title="Confederate States Constitution">\n        C.S. Constitution\n       </a>\n       on March 23.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-facts_2-2">\n        <a href="#cite_note-facts-2">\n         [2]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SecessionConvention_110-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-SecessionConvention-110">\n         [109]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Not all Texans favored secession initially, although many of the same would later support the Southern cause. Texas\'s most notable\n       <a href="/wiki/Union_(American_Civil_War)" title="Union (American Civil War)">\n        Unionist\n       </a>\n       was the state Governor,\n       <a href="/wiki/Sam_Houston" title="Sam Houston">\n        Sam Houston\n       </a>\n       . Not wanting to aggravate the situation, Houston refused two offers from President Lincoln for Union troops to keep him in office. After refusing to swear an oath of allegiance to the Confederacy, Houston was deposed as governor.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SamHoustonHB_111-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-SamHoustonHB-111">\n         [110]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       While far from the\n       <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Theater_of_the_American_Civil_War" title="Eastern Theater of the American Civil War">\n        major battlefields\n       </a>\n       of the\n       <a href="/wiki/American_Civil_War" title="American Civil War">\n        American Civil War\n       </a>\n       , Texas contributed large numbers of men and equipment to the rest of the Confederacy.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CivilwarHB_112-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-CivilwarHB-112">\n         [111]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Union troops briefly\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_Battle_of_Galveston" title="First Battle of Galveston">\n        occupied\n       </a>\n       the state\'s primary port, Galveston. Texas\'s border with Mexico was known as the "backdoor of the Confederacy" because trade occurred at the border, bypassing the Union blockade.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FederalWriter_113-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-FederalWriter-113">\n         [112]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The Confederacy repulsed all Union attempts to shut down this route,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CivilwarHB_112-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-CivilwarHB-112">\n         [111]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       but Texas\'s role as a supply state was marginalized in mid-1863 after the Union capture of the\n       <a href="/wiki/Mississippi_River" title="Mississippi River">\n        Mississippi River\n       </a>\n       . The\n       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Palmito_Ranch" title="Battle of Palmito Ranch">\n        final battle of the Civil War\n       </a>\n       was fought near Brownsville, Texas at\n       <a href="/wiki/Palmito_Ranch_Battlefield" title="Palmito Ranch Battlefield">\n        Palmito Ranch\n       </a>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BattlePR_114-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-BattlePR-114">\n         [113]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       with a Confederate victory.\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Texas descended into anarchy for two months between the\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Battle_of_Appomattox_Courthouse" title="Battle of Appomattox Courthouse">\n        surrender\n       </a>\n       of the\n       <a href="/wiki/Army_of_Northern_Virginia" title="Army of Northern Virginia">\n        Army of Northern Virginia\n       </a>\n       and the assumption of authority by Union General\n       <a href="/wiki/Gordon_Granger" title="Gordon Granger">\n        Gordon Granger\n       </a>\n       . Violence marked the early months of\n       <a href="/wiki/Reconstruction_Era" title="Reconstruction Era">\n        Reconstruction\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CivilwarHB_112-2">\n        <a href="#cite_note-CivilwarHB-112">\n         [111]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <a href="/wiki/Juneteenth" title="Juneteenth">\n        Juneteenth\n       </a>\n       commemorates the announcement of the\n       <a href="/wiki/Emancipation_Proclamation" title="Emancipation Proclamation">\n        Emancipation Proclamation\n       </a>\n       in Galveston by General Gordon Granger, almost two and a half years after the original announcement.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BarriersVoting_115-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-BarriersVoting-115">\n         [114]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Juneteenth_116-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Juneteenth-116">\n         [115]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       President Johnson, in 1866, declared the civilian government restored in Texas.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-readmission_117-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-readmission-117">\n         [116]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Despite not meeting reconstruction requirements, Congress resumed allowing elected Texas representatives into the federal government in 1870. Social volatility continued as the state struggled with agricultural depression and labor issues.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-restoration_118-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-restoration-118">\n         [117]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Like most of the South, the Texas economy was devastated by the War. However, since the state had not been as dependent on slaves as other parts of the South it was able to recover more quickly. The culture in Texas during the later 19th century exhibited many facets of a frontier territory. The state became notorious as a haven for people from other parts of the country who wanted to escape debt, criminal prosecution, or other problems. Indeed, "Gone to Texas" was a common expression for those fleeing the law in other states. Nevertheless, the state also attracted many businessmen and other settlers with more legitimate interests as well.\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The cattle industry continued to thrive though it gradually became less profitable. Cotton and lumber became major industries creating new economic booms in various regions of the state. Railroad networks grew rapidly as did the port at Galveston as commerce between Texas and the rest of the U.S. (and the rest of the world) expanded. As with some other states before, the lumber industry quickly decimated the\n       <a href="/wiki/History_of_Texas_forests" title="History of Texas forests">\n        forests of Texas\n       </a>\n       such that by the early 20th century the major of the forest population in Texas was gone (later conservation efforts restored some of it but never to the level it once was).\n      </p>\n      <h3>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Earlier_20th_century">\n        Earlier 20th century\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lucas_gusher.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="488" data-file-width="410" height="202" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Lucas_gusher.jpg/170px-Lucas_gusher.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Lucas_gusher.jpg/255px-Lucas_gusher.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Lucas_gusher.jpg/340px-Lucas_gusher.jpg 2x" width="170"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lucas_gusher.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         Spindletop, the first major oil gusher\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       In 1900, Texas suffered the deadliest natural disaster in U.S. history during the\n       <a href="/wiki/1900_Galveston_hurricane" title="1900 Galveston hurricane">\n        Galveston hurricane\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-deadhurr_39-2">\n        <a href="#cite_note-deadhurr-39">\n         [38]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       On January 10, 1901, the first major\n       <a href="/wiki/Oil_well" title="Oil well">\n        oil well\n       </a>\n       in Texas,\n       <a href="/wiki/Spindletop" title="Spindletop">\n        Spindletop\n       </a>\n       , was found south of\n       <a href="/wiki/Beaumont,_Texas" title="Beaumont, Texas">\n        Beaumont\n       </a>\n       . Other fields were later discovered nearby in\n       <a href="/wiki/East_Texas_Oil_Field" title="East Texas Oil Field">\n        East Texas\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/West_Texas" title="West Texas">\n        West Texas\n       </a>\n       , and under the\n       <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico" title="Gulf of Mexico">\n        Gulf of Mexico\n       </a>\n       . The resulting "\n       <a href="/wiki/Texas_oil_boom" title="Texas oil boom">\n        oil boom\n       </a>\n       " transformed Texas.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Spindletop_119-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Spindletop-119">\n         [118]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Oil production eventually averaged three million barrels per day at its peak in 1972.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Oil_Gas_120-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Oil_Gas-120">\n         [119]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       In 1901, the Democratic-dominated state legislature passed a bill requiring payment of a\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Poll_tax_(United_States)" title="Poll tax (United States)">\n        poll tax\n       </a>\n       for voting, which effectively\n       <a href="/wiki/Disenfranchisement_after_the_Reconstruction_Era" title="Disenfranchisement after the Reconstruction Era">\n        disenfranchised\n       </a>\n       most blacks, and many poor whites and\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Latinos" title="Latinos">\n        Latinos\n       </a>\n       . In addition, the legislature established\n       <a href="/wiki/White_primaries" title="White primaries">\n        white primaries\n       </a>\n       , ensuring that minorities were excluded from the formal political process. The number of voters dropped dramatically, and the Democrats crushed competition from the Republican and Populist parties.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yale_121-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-yale-121">\n         [120]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-texaspolitics.laits.utexas.edu_122-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-texaspolitics.laits.utexas.edu-122">\n         [121]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The\n       <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Party_of_Texas" title="Socialist Party of Texas">\n        Socialist Party\n       </a>\n       became the second largest party in Texas after 1912,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123">\n        <a href="#cite_note-123">\n         [122]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       coinciding with a large socialist upsurge in the United States during fierce battles in the labor movement and the popularity of national heroes like\n       <a href="/wiki/Eugene_V._Debs" title="Eugene V. Debs">\n        Eugene V. Debs\n       </a>\n       . The Socialists\' popularity soon waned after their vilification by the United States government for their opposition to US involvement in\n       <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">\n        World War I\n       </a>\n       .\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The\n       <a href="/wiki/Great_Depression" title="Great Depression">\n        Great Depression\n       </a>\n       and the\n       <a href="/wiki/Dust_Bowl" title="Dust Bowl">\n        Dust Bowl\n       </a>\n       dealt a double blow to the state\'s economy, which had significantly improved since the Civil War. Migrants abandoned the worst hit sections of Texas during the Dust Bowl years. Especially from this period on, blacks left Texas in the\n       <a href="/wiki/Great_Migration_(African_American)" title="Great Migration (African American)">\n        Great Migration\n       </a>\n       to get work in the Northern United States or California and to escape the oppression of segregation.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TX.26GreatMigration_124-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-TX.26GreatMigration-124">\n         [123]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       In 1940, Texas was 74 percent\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Non-Hispanic_Whites" title="Non-Hispanic Whites">\n        Anglo\n       </a>\n       , 14.4 percent black, and 11.5 percent Hispanic.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125">\n        <a href="#cite_note-125">\n         [124]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       World War II had a dramatic impact on Texas, as federal money poured in to build military bases, munitions factories, POW detention camps and Army hospitals; 750,000 young men left for service; the cities exploded with new industry; the colleges took on new roles; and hundreds of thousands of poor farmers left the fields for much better paying war jobs, never to return to agriculture.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126">\n        <a href="#cite_note-126">\n         [125]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127">\n        <a href="#cite_note-127">\n         [126]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Texas manufactured 3.1 percent of total United States military armaments produced during World War II, ranking eleventh among the 48 states.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128">\n        <a href="#cite_note-128">\n         [127]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Texas modernized and expanded its\n       <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Texas#Public_colleges_and_universities" title="Education in Texas">\n        system of higher education\n       </a>\n       through the 1960s. The state created a comprehensive plan for higher education, funded in large part by oil revenues, and a central state apparatus designed to manage state institutions more efficiently. These changes helped Texas universities receive federal research funds.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Blanton_129-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Blanton-129">\n         [128]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       On November 22, 1963, President\n       <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_John_F._Kennedy" title="Assassination of John F. Kennedy">\n        John F. Kennedy was assassinated\n       </a>\n       in Dallas.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130">\n        <a href="#cite_note-130">\n         [129]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h3>\n       <span id="Economic_and_political_change_(1950\xe2\x80\x93present)">\n       </span>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Economic_and_political_change_.281950.E2.80.93present.29">\n        Economic and political change (1950\xe2\x80\x93present)\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <p>\n       Beginning around the mid-20th century, Texas began to transform from a rural and agricultural state to one that was urban and industrialized.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TSHAsince_131-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-TSHAsince-131">\n         [130]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The state\'s population grew quickly during this period, with large levels of migration from outside the state.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TSHAsince_131-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-TSHAsince-131">\n         [130]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       As a part of the\n       <a href="/wiki/Sun_Belt" title="Sun Belt">\n        Sun Belt\n       </a>\n       Texas experienced strong economic growth, particularly during the 1970s and early 1980s.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TSHAsince_131-2">\n        <a href="#cite_note-TSHAsince-131">\n         [130]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Texas\'s economy diversified, lessening its reliance on the\n       <a href="/wiki/Petroleum_industry" title="Petroleum industry">\n        petroleum industry\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TSHAsince_131-3">\n        <a href="#cite_note-TSHAsince-131">\n         [130]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       By 1990,\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hispanics" title="Hispanics">\n        Hispanics\n       </a>\n       overtook blacks to become the largest minority group in the state.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TSHAsince_131-4">\n        <a href="#cite_note-TSHAsince-131">\n         [130]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       During the late 20th century, the\n       <a href="/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)" title="Republican Party (United States)">\n        Republican Party\n       </a>\n       replaced the\n       <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)" title="Democratic Party (United States)">\n        Democratic Party\n       </a>\n       as the dominant party in the state, as the latter became more\n       <a href="/wiki/Liberalism_in_the_United_States" title="Liberalism in the United States">\n        politically liberal\n       </a>\n       and as demographic changes favored the former.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TSHAsince_131-5">\n        <a href="#cite_note-TSHAsince-131">\n         [130]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h2>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">\n        Government and politics\n       </span>\n      </h2>\n      <p>\n       The current\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Texas_Constitution" title="Texas Constitution">\n        Texas Constitution\n       </a>\n       was adopted in 1876. Like many\n       <a href="/wiki/State_constitution_(United_States)" title="State constitution (United States)">\n        states\n       </a>\n       , it explicitly provides for a separation of powers. The state\'s Bill of Rights is much larger than its\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Bill_of_Rights" title="United States Bill of Rights">\n        federal counterpart\n       </a>\n       , and has provisions unique to Texas.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BillofRights_132-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-BillofRights-132">\n         [131]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h3>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="State_government">\n        State government\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Main article:\n       <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Texas" title="Government of Texas">\n        Government of Texas\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       See also:\n       <a href="/wiki/List_of_Texas_state_agencies" title="List of Texas state agencies">\n        List of Texas state agencies\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Texas_State_Capitol_Night.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="565" data-file-width="1024" height="138" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Texas_State_Capitol_Night.jpg/250px-Texas_State_Capitol_Night.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Texas_State_Capitol_Night.jpg/375px-Texas_State_Capitol_Night.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Texas_State_Capitol_Night.jpg/500px-Texas_State_Capitol_Night.jpg 2x" width="250"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Texas_State_Capitol_Night.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         The\n         <a href="/wiki/Texas_State_Capitol" title="Texas State Capitol">\n          Texas State Capitol\n         </a>\n         at night\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       Texas has a plural\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Executive_branch" title="Executive branch">\n        executive branch\n       </a>\n       system limiting the power of the governor, which is a weak executive compared to some other states. Except for the\n       <a href="/wiki/Secretary_of_State_of_Texas" title="Secretary of State of Texas">\n        Secretary of State\n       </a>\n       , voters elect executive officers independently; thus candidates are directly answerable to the public, not the governor.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pluralexec_133-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-pluralexec-133">\n         [132]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       This election system has led to some executive branches split between parties and reduced the ability of the governor to carry out a program. When\n       <a href="/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)" title="Republican Party (United States)">\n        Republican\n       </a>\n       President\n       <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush" title="George W. Bush">\n        George W. Bush\n       </a>\n       served as Texas\'s governor, the state had a\n       <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)" title="Democratic Party (United States)">\n        Democratic\n       </a>\n       lieutenant governor,\n       <a href="/wiki/Bob_Bullock" title="Bob Bullock">\n        Bob Bullock\n       </a>\n       . The executive branch positions consist of the\n       <a href="/wiki/List_of_Governors_of_Texas" title="List of Governors of Texas">\n        Governor\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Lieutenant_Governor_of_Texas" title="Lieutenant Governor of Texas">\n        Lieutenant Governor\n       </a>\n       , Comptroller of Public Accounts, Land Commissioner, Attorney General, Agriculture Commissioner, the three-member\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Texas_Railroad_Commission" title="Texas Railroad Commission">\n        Texas Railroad Commission\n       </a>\n       , the State Board of Education, and the Secretary of State.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pluralexec_133-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-pluralexec-133">\n         [132]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bicameral" title="Bicameral">\n        bicameral\n       </a>\n       <a href="/wiki/Texas_Legislature" title="Texas Legislature">\n        Texas Legislature\n       </a>\n       consists of the\n       <a href="/wiki/Texas_House_of_Representatives" title="Texas House of Representatives">\n        House of Representatives\n       </a>\n       , with 150 members, and a\n       <a href="/wiki/Texas_Senate" title="Texas Senate">\n        Senate\n       </a>\n       , with 31 members. The\n       <a href="/wiki/Speaker_of_the_Texas_House_of_Representatives" title="Speaker of the Texas House of Representatives">\n        Speaker of the House\n       </a>\n       leads the House, and the lieutenant governor, the Senate.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Legislature_Members_134-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Legislature_Members-134">\n         [133]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The Legislature meets in regular session biennially for just over 100 days, but the governor can call for special sessions as often as desired (notably, the Legislature cannot call itself into session).\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Special_Sessions_135-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Special_Sessions-135">\n         [134]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The state\'s\n       <a href="/wiki/Fiscal_year" title="Fiscal year">\n        fiscal year\n       </a>\n       spans from the previous calendar year\'s September 1 to the current year\'s August 31. Thus, the FY 2015 dates from September 1, 2014 through August 31, 2015.\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The\n       <a href="/wiki/Judiciary_of_Texas" title="Judiciary of Texas">\n        judiciary of Texas\n       </a>\n       is one of the most complex in the United States, with many layers and overlapping jurisdictions. Texas has two courts of last resort: the\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Texas_Supreme_Court" title="Texas Supreme Court">\n        Texas Supreme Court\n       </a>\n       , for civil cases, and the\n       <a href="/wiki/Texas_Court_of_Criminal_Appeals" title="Texas Court of Criminal Appeals">\n        Texas Court of Criminal Appeals\n       </a>\n       . Except for some municipal benches, partisan elections select judges at all levels of the judiciary; the governor fills vacancies by appointment.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Judiciary_136-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Judiciary-136">\n         [135]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Texas is notable for its use of capital punishment, having led the country in executions since capital punishment was reinstated in the\n       <i>\n        <a href="/wiki/Gregg_v._Georgia" title="Gregg v. Georgia">\n         Gregg v. Georgia\n        </a>\n       </i>\n       case (see\n       <a href="/wiki/Capital_punishment_in_Texas" title="Capital punishment in Texas">\n        Capital punishment in Texas\n       </a>\n       ).\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The\n       <a href="/wiki/Texas_Ranger_Division" title="Texas Ranger Division">\n        Texas Ranger Division\n       </a>\n       of the\n       <a href="/wiki/Texas_Department_of_Public_Safety" title="Texas Department of Public Safety">\n        Texas Department of Public Safety\n       </a>\n       is a\n       <a href="/wiki/Police" title="Police">\n        law enforcement agency\n       </a>\n       with statewide\n       <a href="/wiki/Jurisdiction" title="Jurisdiction">\n        jurisdiction\n       </a>\n       . Over the years, the Texas Rangers have investigated crimes ranging from murder to political corruption. They have acted as\n       <a href="/wiki/Riot" title="Riot">\n        riot\n       </a>\n       police and as detectives, protected the Texas governor, tracked down fugitives, and functioned as a paramilitary force both for the republic and the state. The Texas Rangers were unofficially created by\n       <a href="/wiki/Stephen_F._Austin" title="Stephen F. Austin">\n        Stephen F. Austin\n       </a>\n       in 1823 and formally constituted in 1835. The Rangers were integral to several important events of Texas history and some of the best-known criminal cases in the history of the\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/American_Old_West" title="American Old West">\n        Old West\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TexasRangers_137-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-TexasRangers-137">\n         [136]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The Texas constitution defines the responsibilities of county governments, which serve as agents of the state. What are called commissioners court and court judges are elected to serve as the administrative arm. Most cities in the state, those over 5,000 in population, have\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Home-rule" title="Home-rule">\n        home-rule\n       </a>\n       governments. The vast majority of these have charters for\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Council-manager" title="Council-manager">\n        council-manager\n       </a>\n       forms of government, by which voters elect council members, who hire a professional city manager as operating officer.\n      </p>\n      <h3>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">\n        Politics\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Main article:\n       <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Texas" title="Politics of Texas">\n        Politics of Texas\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Further information:\n       <a href="/wiki/Political_party_strength_in_Texas" title="Political party strength in Texas">\n        Political party strength in Texas\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <table class="wikitable" style="float:right; font-size:79%; margin:10px">\n       <caption>\n        <b>\n         Texas Presidential elections results\n        </b>\n        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138">\n         <a href="#cite_note-138">\n          [137]\n         </a>\n        </sup>\n       </caption>\n       <tr style="background:lightgrey;">\n        <th>\n         Year\n        </th>\n        <th>\n         <a href="/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)" title="Republican Party (United States)">\n          Republican\n         </a>\n        </th>\n        <th>\n         <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)" title="Democratic Party (United States)">\n          Democratic\n         </a>\n        </th>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <td style="text-align:center; background:#fff3f3;">\n         <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2016" title="United States presidential election, 2016">\n          2016\n         </a>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:center; background:#fff3f3;">\n         <b>\n          52.23%\n         </b>\n         <i>\n          4,685,047\n         </i>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:center; background:#f0f0ff;">\n         43.24%\n         <i>\n          3,877,868\n         </i>\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <td style="text-align:center; background:#fff3f3;">\n         <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2012" title="United States presidential election, 2012">\n          2012\n         </a>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:center; background:#fff3f3;">\n         <b>\n          57.15%\n         </b>\n         <i>\n          4,569,843\n         </i>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:center; background:#f0f0ff;">\n         41.37%\n         <i>\n          3,308,124\n         </i>\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <td style="text-align:center; background:#fff3f3;">\n         <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2008" title="United States presidential election, 2008">\n          2008\n         </a>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:center; background:#fff3f3;">\n         <b>\n          55.39%\n         </b>\n         <i>\n          4,479,328\n         </i>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:center; background:#f0f0ff;">\n         43.63%\n         <i>\n          3,528,633\n         </i>\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <td style="text-align:center; background:#fff3f3;">\n         <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2004" title="United States presidential election, 2004">\n          2004\n         </a>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:center; background:#fff3f3;">\n         <b>\n          61.09%\n         </b>\n         <i>\n          4,526,917\n         </i>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:center; background:#f0f0ff;">\n         38.30%\n         <i>\n          2,832,704\n         </i>\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <td style="text-align:center; background:#fff3f3;">\n         <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2000" title="United States presidential election, 2000">\n          2000\n         </a>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:center; background:#fff3f3;">\n         <b>\n          59.30%\n         </b>\n         <i>\n          3,799,639\n         </i>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:center; background:#f0f0ff;">\n         38.11%\n         <i>\n          2,433,746\n         </i>\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <td style="text-align:center; background:#fff3f3;">\n         <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1996" title="United States presidential election, 1996">\n          1996\n         </a>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:center; background:#fff3f3;">\n         <b>\n          48.80%\n         </b>\n         <i>\n          2,736,166\n         </i>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:center; background:#f0f0ff;">\n         43.81%\n         <i>\n          2,459,683\n         </i>\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <td style="text-align:center; background:#fff3f3;">\n         <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1992" title="United States presidential election, 1992">\n          1992\n         </a>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:center; background:#fff3f3;">\n         <b>\n          40.61%\n         </b>\n         <i>\n          2,496,071\n         </i>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:center; background:#f0f0ff;">\n         37.11%\n         <i>\n          2,281,815\n         </i>\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <td style="text-align:center; background:#fff3f3;">\n         <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1988" title="United States presidential election, 1988">\n          1988\n         </a>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:center; background:#fff3f3;">\n         <b>\n          56.01%\n         </b>\n         <i>\n          3,036,829\n         </i>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:center; background:#f0f0ff;">\n         43.41%\n         <i>\n          2,352,748\n         </i>\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <td style="text-align:center; background:#fff3f3;">\n         <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1984" title="United States presidential election, 1984">\n          1984\n         </a>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:center; background:#fff3f3;">\n         <b>\n          63.58%\n         </b>\n         <i>\n          3,433,428\n         </i>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:center; background:#f0f0ff;">\n         36.18%\n         <i>\n          1,949,276\n         </i>\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <td style="text-align:center; background:#fff3f3;">\n         <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1980" title="United States presidential election, 1980">\n          1980\n         </a>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:center;
