background:#fff3f3;">\n         <b>\n          55.30%\n         </b>\n         <i>\n          2,510,705\n         </i>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:center; background:#f0f0ff;">\n         41.51%\n         <i>\n          1,881,148\n         </i>\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n      </table>\n      <h4>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Political_history">\n        Political history\n       </span>\n      </h4>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lbj2.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5552" data-file-width="3696" height="330" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Lbj2.jpg/220px-Lbj2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Lbj2.jpg/330px-Lbj2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Lbj2.jpg/440px-Lbj2.jpg 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lbj2.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         <a href="/wiki/Lyndon_B._Johnson" title="Lyndon B. Johnson">\n          Lyndon B. Johnson\n         </a>\n         , Texan and 36th president of the United States\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       In the 1870s, white Democrats wrested power back in the state legislature from the biracial coalition at the end of Reconstruction. In the early 20th century, the legislature passed bills to impose\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Poll_tax_(United_States)" title="Poll tax (United States)">\n        poll taxes\n       </a>\n       , followed by\n       <a href="/wiki/White_primaries" title="White primaries">\n        white primaries\n       </a>\n       ; these measures effectively\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Disfranchisement_after_Reconstruction_era" title="Disfranchisement after Reconstruction era">\n        disfranchised\n       </a>\n       most blacks, poor whites and Mexican Americans.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yale_121-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-yale-121">\n         [120]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-texaspolitics.laits.utexas.edu_122-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-texaspolitics.laits.utexas.edu-122">\n         [121]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       In the 1890s, 100,000 blacks voted in the state; by 1906, only 5,000 could vote.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MOTTU_139-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-MOTTU-139">\n         [138]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       As a result, the Democratic Party dominated\n       <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Texas" title="Politics of Texas">\n        Texas politics\n       </a>\n       from the turn of the century, imposing racial segregation and white supremacy. It held power until after passage in the mid-1960s of national civil rights legislation enforcing constitutional rights of all citizens.\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Although Texas was essentially a one-party state during this time and the Democratic primary was viewed as "the real election," the Democratic Party had conservative and liberal factions, which became more pronounced after the\n       <a href="/wiki/New_Deal" title="New Deal">\n        New Deal\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PoliticalPartiesTSHA_140-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-PoliticalPartiesTSHA-140">\n         [139]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Additionally, several factions of the party briefly split during the 1930s and 1940s.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PoliticalPartiesTSHA_140-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-PoliticalPartiesTSHA-140">\n         [139]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The state\'s conservative white voters began to support Republican presidential candidates by the mid-20th century. After this period, they supported Republicans for local and state offices as well, and most whites became Republican Party members.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SouthWon_141-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-SouthWon-141">\n         [140]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The party also attracted some minorities, but many have continued to vote for Democratic candidates. The shift to the Republican Party is much-attributed to the fact that the Democratic Party became increasingly\n       <a href="/wiki/Liberalism_in_the_United_States" title="Liberalism in the United States">\n        liberal\n       </a>\n       during the 20th century, and thus increasingly out-of-touch with the average Texas voter.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HistoryTXvoters_142-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-HistoryTXvoters-142">\n         [141]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       As Texas was always a\n       <a href="/wiki/Conservatism_in_the_United_States" title="Conservatism in the United States">\n        conservative\n       </a>\n       state, voters switched to the GOP, which now more closely reflected their beliefs.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HistoryTXvoters_142-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-HistoryTXvoters-142">\n         [141]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PBSredstate_143-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-PBSredstate-143">\n         [142]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Commentators have also attributed the shift to Republican political consultant\n       <a href="/wiki/Karl_Rove" title="Karl Rove">\n        Karl Rove\n       </a>\n       , who managed numerous political campaigns in Texas in the 1980s and 1990s.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PBSredstate_143-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-PBSredstate-143">\n         [142]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Other stated reasons included court-ordered redistricting and the demographic shift in relation to the\n       <a href="/wiki/Sun_Belt" title="Sun Belt">\n        Sun Belt\n       </a>\n       that favored the Republican Party and conservatism.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TSHAsince_131-6">\n        <a href="#cite_note-TSHAsince-131">\n         [130]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The\n       <a href="/wiki/2003_Texas_redistricting" title="2003 Texas redistricting">\n        2003 Texas redistricting\n       </a>\n       of Congressional districts led by Republican\n       <a href="/wiki/Tom_DeLay" title="Tom DeLay">\n        Tom DeLay\n       </a>\n       , was called by the\n       <i>\n        New York Times\n       </i>\n       "an extreme case of partisan\n       <a href="/wiki/Gerrymandering" title="Gerrymandering">\n        gerrymandering\n       </a>\n       ".\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYTGerry_144-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-NYTGerry-144">\n         [143]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       A group of Democratic legislators, the "\n       <a href="/wiki/Texas_Eleven" title="Texas Eleven">\n        Texas Eleven\n       </a>\n       ", fled the state in a\n       <a href="/wiki/Quorum" title="Quorum">\n        quorum\n       </a>\n       -busting effort to prevent the legislature from acting, but was unsuccessful.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tex11_145-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Tex11-145">\n         [144]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The state had already redistricted following the 2000 census. Despite these efforts, the legislature passed a map heavily in favor of Republicans, based on 2000 data and ignoring the estimated nearly one million new residents in the state since that date. Career attorneys and analysts at the Department of Justice objected to the plan as diluting the votes of African American and Hispanic voters, but political appointees overrode them and approved it.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYTGerry_144-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-NYTGerry-144">\n         [143]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Legal challenges to the redistricting reached the national\n       <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States" title="Supreme Court of the United States">\n        Supreme Court\n       </a>\n       in the case\n       <i>\n        <a href="/wiki/League_of_United_Latin_American_Citizens_v._Perry" title="League of United Latin American Citizens v. Perry">\n         League of United Latin American Citizens v. Perry\n        </a>\n       </i>\n       (2006), but the court ruled in favor of the state (and Republicans).\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146">\n        <a href="#cite_note-146">\n         [145]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       In the\n       <a href="/wiki/Texas_elections,_2014" title="Texas elections, 2014">\n        2014 Texas elections\n       </a>\n       , the\n       <a href="/wiki/Tea_Party_movement" title="Tea Party movement">\n        Tea Party movement\n       </a>\n       made large gains, with numerous Tea Party favorites being elected into office, including\n       <a href="/wiki/Dan_Patrick_(politician)" title="Dan Patrick (politician)">\n        Dan Patrick\n       </a>\n       as lieutenant governor,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fernandez_147-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Fernandez-147">\n         [146]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148">\n        <a href="#cite_note-148">\n         [147]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <a href="/wiki/Ken_Paxton" title="Ken Paxton">\n        Ken Paxton\n       </a>\n       as attorney general,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fernandez_147-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Fernandez-147">\n         [146]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Grissom_149-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Grissom-149">\n         [148]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       in addition to numerous other candidates\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Grissom_149-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Grissom-149">\n         [148]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       including conservative Republican\n       <a href="/wiki/Greg_Abbott" title="Greg Abbott">\n        Greg Abbott\n       </a>\n       as governor.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150">\n        <a href="#cite_note-150">\n         [149]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h4>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Texas_politics_today">\n        Texas politics today\n       </span>\n      </h4>\n      <p>\n       Texas voters lean toward\n       <a href="/wiki/Fiscal_conservatism" title="Fiscal conservatism">\n        fiscal conservatism\n       </a>\n       , while enjoying the benefits of huge federal investment in the state in military and other facilities achieved by the power of the Solid South in the 20th century. They also tend to have\n       <a href="/wiki/Social_conservatism" title="Social conservatism">\n        socially conservative\n       </a>\n       values.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TPoliticalCulture1_151-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-TPoliticalCulture1-151">\n         [150]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TPoliticalCulture2_152-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-TPoliticalCulture2-152">\n         [151]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Since 1980, most Texas voters have supported Republican presidential candidates. In 2000 and 2004, Republican\n       <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush" title="George W. Bush">\n        George W. Bush\n       </a>\n       won Texas with 60.1 percent of the vote, partly due to his "favorite son" status as a former governor of the state.\n       <a href="/wiki/John_McCain" title="John McCain">\n        John McCain\n       </a>\n       won the state in\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2008" title="United States presidential election, 2008">\n        2008\n       </a>\n       , but with a smaller margin of victory compared to Bush at 55 percent of the vote. Austin, Dallas, Houston, and San Antonio consistently lean Democratic in both local and statewide elections.\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Residents of counties along the\n       <a href="/wiki/Rio_Grande" title="Rio Grande">\n        Rio Grande\n       </a>\n       closer to the\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mexico-United_States_border" title="Mexico-United States border">\n        Mexico-United States border\n       </a>\n       , where there are many Latino residents, generally vote for Democratic Party candidates, while most other rural and suburban areas of Texas have shifted to voting for Republican Party candidates.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2000electionresults_153-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-2000electionresults-153">\n         [152]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2004electionresults_154-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-2004electionresults-154">\n         [153]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       As of the\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_elections,_2014" title="United States elections, 2014">\n        general elections of 2014\n       </a>\n       , a large majority of the members of Texas\'s\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._House_of_Representatives" title="U.S. House of Representatives">\n        U.S. House\n       </a>\n       delegation are\n       <a href="/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)" title="Republican Party (United States)">\n        Republican\n       </a>\n       , along with both\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Senators" title="U.S. Senators">\n        U.S. Senators\n       </a>\n       . In the\n       <a href="/wiki/114th_United_States_Congress" title="114th United States Congress">\n        114th United States Congress\n       </a>\n       , of the 36\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Texas_Congressional_Districts" title="Texas Congressional Districts">\n        Congressional districts in Texas\n       </a>\n       , 25 are held by Republicans and 11 by Democrats. Texas\'s Senators are\n       <a href="/wiki/John_Cornyn" title="John Cornyn">\n        John Cornyn\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Ted_Cruz" title="Ted Cruz">\n        Ted Cruz\n       </a>\n       . Since 1994, Texans have not elected a Democrat to a statewide office. The state\'s Democratic voters are made up primarily by liberal and\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Minority_groups" title="Minority groups">\n        minority groups\n       </a>\n       in Austin, San Antonio, Dallas, Houston, Beaumont, and El Paso, as well as minority voters in East Texas and South Texas.\n      </p>\n      <table border="1" cellpadding="3" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse; font-size: 98%;">\n       <tr style="background:#e9e9e9;">\n        <th colspan="7">\n         <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election_in_Texas,_2016" title="United States presidential election in Texas, 2016">\n          United States presidential election in Texas, 2016\n         </a>\n         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155">\n          <a href="#cite_note-155">\n           [154]\n          </a>\n         </sup>\n        </th>\n       </tr>\n       <tr style="background:#eee; text-align:center;">\n        <th colspan="2" style="width: 15em">\n         Party\n        </th>\n        <th style="width: 10em">\n         Candidate\n        </th>\n        <th style="width: 10em">\n         Running mate\n        </th>\n        <th style="width: 5em">\n         Votes\n        </th>\n        <th style="width: 5em">\n         Percentage\n        </th>\n        <th style="width: 5em">\n         Electoral votes\n        </th>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <th style="background:#f33; width:3px;">\n        </th>\n        <td style="width: 130px">\n         <b>\n          <a href="/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)" title="Republican Party (United States)">\n           Republican\n          </a>\n         </b>\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         <b>\n          <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">\n           Donald Trump\n          </a>\n         </b>\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         <b>\n          <a href="/wiki/Mike_Pence" title="Mike Pence">\n           Mike Pence\n          </a>\n         </b>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:right;">\n         <b>\n          4,685,047\n         </b>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:right;">\n         <b>\n          52.23%\n         </b>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:right;">\n         <b>\n          36\n         </b>\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <th style="background:#33f; width:3px;">\n        </th>\n        <td style="width: 130px">\n         <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)" title="Democratic Party (United States)">\n          Democratic\n         </a>\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         <a href="/wiki/Hillary_Clinton" title="Hillary Clinton">\n          Hillary Clinton\n         </a>\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         <a href="/wiki/Tim_Kaine" title="Tim Kaine">\n          Tim Kaine\n         </a>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:right;">\n         3,877,868\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:right;">\n         43.24%\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:right;">\n         0\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <th style="background:gold; width:3px;">\n        </th>\n        <td style="width: 130px">\n         <a href="/wiki/Libertarian_Party_(United_States)" title="Libertarian Party (United States)">\n          Libertarian\n         </a>\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         <a href="/wiki/Gary_Johnson" title="Gary Johnson">\n          Gary Johnson\n         </a>\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/William_Weld" title="William Weld">\n          William Weld\n         </a>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:right;">\n         283,492\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:right;">\n         3.16%\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:right;">\n         0\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <th style="background:#0bda51; width:3px;">\n        </th>\n        <td style="width: 130px">\n         <a href="/wiki/Green_Party_of_the_United_States" title="Green Party of the United States">\n          Green\n         </a>\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         <a href="/wiki/Jill_Stein" title="Jill Stein">\n          Jill Stein\n         </a>\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         <a href="/wiki/Ajamu_Baraka" title="Ajamu Baraka">\n          Ajamu Baraka\n         </a>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:right;">\n         71,558\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:right;">\n         0.80%\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:right;">\n         0\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <th style="background:grey; width:3px;">\n        </th>\n        <td style="width: 130px">\n         <a href="/wiki/Write-in_candidate" title="Write-in candidate">\n          Write-in\n         </a>\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         Various candidates\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         Various candidates\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:right;">\n         51,261\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:right;">\n         0.57%\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:right;">\n         0\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <th style="background:#f33; width:3px;">\n        </th>\n        <td style="width: 130px">\n         <a href="/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)" title="Republican Party (United States)">\n          Republican\n         </a>\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         <a href="/wiki/John_Kasich" title="John Kasich">\n          John Kasich\n         </a>\n         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Elector_156-0">\n          <a href="#cite_note-Elector-156">\n           [a]\n          </a>\n         </sup>\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         <a href="/wiki/Carly_Fiorina" title="Carly Fiorina">\n          Carly Fiorina\n         </a>\n         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Elector_156-1">\n          <a href="#cite_note-Elector-156">\n           [a]\n          </a>\n         </sup>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:right;">\n         0\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:right;">\n         0.0%\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:right;">\n         1\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <th style="background:gold; width:3px;">\n        </th>\n        <td style="width: 130px">\n         <a href="/wiki/Libertarian_Party_(United_States)" title="Libertarian Party (United States)">\n          Libertarian\n         </a>\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         <a href="/wiki/Ron_Paul" title="Ron Paul">\n          Ron Paul\n         </a>\n         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Elector_156-2">\n          <a href="#cite_note-Elector-156">\n           [a]\n          </a>\n         </sup>\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         <a href="/wiki/Mike_Pence" title="Mike Pence">\n          Mike Pence\n         </a>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:right;">\n         0\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:right;">\n         0.0%\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:right;">\n         1\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr style="background:#eee; text-align:right;">\n        <td colspan="4">\n         <b>\n          Totals\n         </b>\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         <b>\n          8,969,226\n         </b>\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         <b>\n          100.00%\n         </b>\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         <b>\n          38\n         </b>\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr style="background:#eee; text-align:right;">\n        <td colspan="6">\n         Voter turnout (voting age population)\n        </td>\n        <td>\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n      </table>\n      <h3>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">\n        Administrative divisions\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       See also:\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Texas_counties" title="List of Texas counties">\n        List of Texas counties\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       Texas has 254\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Counties_of_the_United_States" title="Counties of the United States">\n        counties\n       </a>\n       \xe2\x80\x94 the most nationwide. Each county runs on\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Commissioners%27_Court" title="Commissioners\' Court">\n        Commissioners\' Court\n       </a>\n       system consisting of four elected commissioners (one from each of four precincts in the county, roughly divided according to population) and a county judge elected at large from the entire county. County government runs similar to a "weak"\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mayor-council" title="Mayor-council">\n        mayor-council\n       </a>\n       system; the county judge has no veto authority, but votes along with the other commissioners.\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Although Texas permits cities and counties to enter "interlocal agreements" to share services, the state does not allow\n       <a href="/wiki/Consolidated_city-county" title="Consolidated city-county">\n        consolidated city-county\n       </a>\n       governments, nor does it have\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Metropolitan_government" title="Metropolitan government">\n        metropolitan governments\n       </a>\n       . Counties are not granted\n       <a href="/wiki/Home_rule" title="Home rule">\n        home rule\n       </a>\n       status; their powers are strictly defined by state law. The state does not have townships\xe2\x80\x94 areas within a county are either incorporated or unincorporated. Incorporated areas are part of a municipality. The county provides limited services to unincorporated areas and to some smaller incorporated areas. Municipalities are classified either "general law" cities or "home rule".\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-homerule_157-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-homerule-157">\n         [155]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       A municipality may elect home rule status once it exceeds 5,000 population with voter approval.\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Texas also permits the creation of "special districts", which provide limited services. The most common is the\n       <a href="/wiki/School_district" title="School district">\n        school district\n       </a>\n       , but can also include hospital districts, community college districts, and utility districts (one utility district located near Austin was the plaintiff in\n       <a href="/wiki/Northwest_Austin_Municipal_Utility_District_No._1_v._Holder" title="Northwest Austin Municipal Utility District No. 1 v. Holder">\n        a landmark Supreme Court case involving the Voting Rights Act\n       </a>\n       ).\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Municipal, school district, and special district elections are\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nonpartisan" title="Nonpartisan">\n        nonpartisan\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-reqvote_158-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-reqvote-158">\n         [156]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       though the party affiliation of a candidate may be well-known. County and state elections are partisan.\n      </p>\n      <h3>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Criminal_law">\n        Criminal law\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <p>\n       Texas has a reputation of very harsh criminal punishment for criminal offenses. It is one of the 32 states that practice\n       <a href="/wiki/Capital_punishment_in_Texas" title="Capital punishment in Texas">\n        capital punishment\n       </a>\n       , and since the\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/US_Supreme_Court" title="US Supreme Court">\n        US Supreme Court\n       </a>\n       allowed capital punishment to resume in 1976, 40% of all US executions have taken place in Texas.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159">\n        <a href="#cite_note-159">\n         [157]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       As of 2008, Texas had the 4th highest\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Incarceration_rate" title="Incarceration rate">\n        incarceration rate\n       </a>\n       in the US.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160">\n        <a href="#cite_note-160">\n         [158]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Texas also has strong\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Self_defense" title="Self defense">\n        self defense\n       </a>\n       laws, allowing citizens to use lethal force to defend themselves, their families, or their property.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161">\n        <a href="#cite_note-161">\n         [159]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h2>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">\n        Economy\n       </span>\n      </h2>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Main article:\n       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Texas" title="Economy of Texas">\n        Economy of Texas\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       See also:\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Texas_locations_by_per_capita_income" title="Texas locations by per capita income">\n        Texas locations by per capita income\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:NASA_Neutral_Buoyancy_Laboratory_Astronaut_Training.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="800" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/NASA_Neutral_Buoyancy_Laboratory_Astronaut_Training.jpg/220px-NASA_Neutral_Buoyancy_Laboratory_Astronaut_Training.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/NASA_Neutral_Buoyancy_Laboratory_Astronaut_Training.jpg/330px-NASA_Neutral_Buoyancy_Laboratory_Astronaut_Training.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/NASA_Neutral_Buoyancy_Laboratory_Astronaut_Training.jpg/440px-NASA_Neutral_Buoyancy_Laboratory_Astronaut_Training.jpg 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:NASA_Neutral_Buoyancy_Laboratory_Astronaut_Training.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         Astronaut training at the\n         <a href="/wiki/Johnson_Space_Center" title="Johnson Space Center">\n          Johnson Space Center\n         </a>\n         in\n         <a href="/wiki/Houston" title="Houston">\n          Houston\n         </a>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       As of 2014, Texas had a\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gross_state_product" title="Gross state product">\n        gross state product\n       </a>\n       (GSP) of $1.648 trillion, the\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_U.S._states_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of U.S. states by GDP (nominal)">\n        second highest\n       </a>\n       in the U.S.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162">\n        <a href="#cite_note-162">\n         [160]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Its GSP is\n       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">\n        greater than the GDPs\n       </a>\n       of Australia and South Korea, which are the world\'s 12th- and 13th-largest economies, respectively. Texas\' economy is the fourth-largest of any\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_country_subdivisions_by_GDP_over_USD_100_billions" title="List of country subdivisions by GDP over USD 100 billions">\n        country subdivision\n       </a>\n       globally, behind England (as part of the UK), California, and\n       <a href="/wiki/Tokyo_Prefecture" title="Tokyo Prefecture">\n        Tokyo Prefecture\n       </a>\n       . Its\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_U.S._states_by_GDP_per_capita_(nominal)" title="List of U.S. states by GDP per capita (nominal)">\n        Per Capita personal income\n       </a>\n       in 2009 was $36,484, ranking 29th in the nation.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-economy1_163-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-economy1-163">\n         [161]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Geo_Map_of_Income_by_Location_in_Texas_(2014).png">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="882" data-file-width="802" height="242" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Geo_Map_of_Income_by_Location_in_Texas_%282014%29.png/220px-Geo_Map_of_Income_by_Location_in_Texas_%282014%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Geo_Map_of_Income_by_Location_in_Texas_%282014%29.png/330px-Geo_Map_of_Income_by_Location_in_Texas_%282014%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Geo_Map_of_Income_by_Location_in_Texas_%282014%29.png/440px-Geo_Map_of_Income_by_Location_in_Texas_%282014%29.png 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Geo_Map_of_Income_by_Location_in_Texas_(2014).png" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         A geomap depicting the income, by county, in Texas as of 2014\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       Texas\'s large population, abundance of natural resources, thriving cities and leading centers of higher education have contributed to a large and diverse economy. Since oil was discovered, the state\'s economy has reflected the state of the petroleum industry. In recent times, urban centers of the state have increased in size, containing two-thirds of the population in 2005. The state\'s economic growth has led to\n       <a href="/wiki/Urban_sprawl" title="Urban sprawl">\n        urban sprawl\n       </a>\n       and its associated symptoms.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-economy1_163-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-economy1-163">\n         [161]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       As of April 2013, the state\'s unemployment rate is 6.4 percent.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164">\n        <a href="#cite_note-164">\n         [162]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       In 2010,\n       <i>\n        Site Selection Magazine\n       </i>\n       ranked Texas as the most business-friendly state in the nation, in part because of the state\'s three-billion-dollar\n       <a href="/wiki/Texas_Enterprise_Fund" title="Texas Enterprise Fund">\n        Texas Enterprise Fund\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1businessclimate_165-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-1businessclimate-165">\n         [163]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Texas has the joint-highest number of\n       <a href="/wiki/Fortune_500" title="Fortune 500">\n        Fortune 500\n       </a>\n       company headquarters in the United States, along with California.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166">\n        <a href="#cite_note-166">\n         [164]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167">\n        <a href="#cite_note-167">\n         [165]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       In 2010, there were 346,000 millionaires in Texas, constituting the second-largest population of millionaires in the nation.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168">\n        <a href="#cite_note-168">\n         [166]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169">\n        <a href="#cite_note-169">\n         [167]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h3>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Taxation">\n        Taxation\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <p>\n       Texas has a "low taxes, low services" reputation.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TPoliticalCulture1_151-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-TPoliticalCulture1-151">\n         [150]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       According to the\n       <a href="/wiki/Tax_Foundation" title="Tax Foundation">\n        Tax Foundation\n       </a>\n       , Texans\' state and local tax burdens rank among the lowest in the nation, 7th lowest nationally; state and local taxes cost $3,580 per capita, or 8.4 percent of resident incomes.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TaxFound_170-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-TaxFound-170">\n         [168]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Texas is one of seven states that lack a\n       <a href="/wiki/State_income_tax" title="State income tax">\n        state income tax\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TaxFound_170-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-TaxFound-170">\n         [168]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-incometax_171-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-incometax-171">\n         [169]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Instead, the state collects revenue from\n       <a href="/wiki/Property_tax" title="Property tax">\n        property taxes\n       </a>\n       (though these are collected at the county, city, and school district level; Texas has a state constitutional prohibition against a state property tax) and\n       <a href="/wiki/Sales_tax" title="Sales tax">\n        sales taxes\n       </a>\n       . The state sales tax rate is 6.25 percent,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TaxFound_170-2">\n        <a href="#cite_note-TaxFound-170">\n         [168]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172">\n        <a href="#cite_note-172">\n         [170]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       but local taxing jurisdictions (cities, counties, special purpose districts, and transit authorities) may also impose sales and use tax up to 2 percent for a total maximum combined rate of 8.25 percent.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173">\n        <a href="#cite_note-173">\n         [171]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Texas is a "tax donor state"; in 2005, for every dollar Texans paid to the federal government in\n       <a href="/wiki/Income_tax_in_the_United_States" title="Income tax in the United States">\n        federal income taxes\n       </a>\n       , the state got back about $0.94 in benefits.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TaxFound_170-3">\n        <a href="#cite_note-TaxFound-170">\n         [168]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       To attract business, Texas has incentive programs worth $19 billion per year (2012); more than any other US state.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174">\n        <a href="#cite_note-174">\n         [172]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175">\n        <a href="#cite_note-175">\n         [173]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h3>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Agriculture_and_mining">\n        Agriculture and mining\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:West_Texas_Cotton.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1125" data-file-width="1500" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/5/50/West_Texas_Cotton.jpg/220px-West_Texas_Cotton.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/5/50/West_Texas_Cotton.jpg/330px-West_Texas_Cotton.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/5/50/West_Texas_Cotton.jpg/440px-West_Texas_Cotton.jpg 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:West_Texas_Cotton.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         Cotton modules after being harvested in West Texas\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Oil_well.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="640" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Oil_well.jpg/220px-Oil_well.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Oil_well.jpg/330px-Oil_well.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Oil_well.jpg/440px-Oil_well.jpg 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Oil_well.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         An oil well\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GreenMountainWindFarm_Fluvanna_2004.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1360" data-file-width="2048" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/GreenMountainWindFarm_Fluvanna_2004.jpg/220px-GreenMountainWindFarm_Fluvanna_2004.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/GreenMountainWindFarm_Fluvanna_2004.jpg/330px-GreenMountainWindFarm_Fluvanna_2004.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/GreenMountainWindFarm_Fluvanna_2004.jpg/440px-GreenMountainWindFarm_Fluvanna_2004.jpg 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:GreenMountainWindFarm_Fluvanna_2004.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         <a href="/wiki/Brazos_Wind_Farm" title="Brazos Wind Farm">\n          Brazos Wind Farm\n         </a>\n         in the plains of West Texas\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GodPod.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="384" data-file-width="512" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/GodPod.jpg/220px-GodPod.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/GodPod.jpg/330px-GodPod.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/GodPod.jpg/440px-GodPod.jpg 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:GodPod.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         <a href="/wiki/Electronic_Data_Systems" title="Electronic Data Systems">\n          Electronic Data Systems\n         </a>\n         headquarters in\n         <a href="/wiki/Plano,_Texas" title="Plano, Texas">\n          Plano\n         </a>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       Texas has the most farms and the highest acreage in the United States. The state is ranked #1 for revenue generated from total livestock and livestock products. It is ranked #2 for total agricultural revenue, behind California.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-netstateecon_176-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-netstateecon-176">\n         [174]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       At $7.4 billion or 56.7 percent of Texas\' annual agricultural cash receipts, beef cattle production represents the largest single segment of Texas agriculture. This is followed by cotton at $1.9 billion (14.6 percent), greenhouse/nursery at $1.5 billion (11.4 percent), broilers at $1.3 billion (10 percent), and dairy products at $947 million (7.3 percent).\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EMMA2013_177-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-EMMA2013-177">\n         [175]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Texas leads the nation in the production of cattle, horses, sheep, goats, wool, mohair and hay.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EMMA2013_177-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-EMMA2013-177">\n         [175]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The state also leads the nation in production of cotton\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-netstateecon_176-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-netstateecon-176">\n         [174]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178">\n        <a href="#cite_note-178">\n         [176]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       which is the number one crop grown in the state in terms of value.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179">\n        <a href="#cite_note-179">\n         [177]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The state grows significant amounts of cereal crops and produce.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-netstateecon_176-2">\n        <a href="#cite_note-netstateecon-176">\n         [174]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Texas has a large commercial fishing industry. With mineral resources, Texas leads in creating cement, crushed stone, lime, salt, sand and gravel.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-netstateecon_176-3">\n        <a href="#cite_note-netstateecon-176">\n         [174]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Texas throughout the 21st century has been\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Drought_in_the_United_States" title="Drought in the United States">\n        hammered by drought\n       </a>\n       . This has cost the state billions of dollars in livestock and crops.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TexasReuters_180-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-TexasReuters-180">\n         [178]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h3>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">\n        Energy\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       See also:\n       <a href="/wiki/Deregulation_of_the_Texas_electricity_market" title="Deregulation of the Texas electricity market">\n        Deregulation of the Texas electricity market\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       Ever since the discovery of oil at\n       <a href="/wiki/Spindletop" title="Spindletop">\n        Spindletop\n       </a>\n       , energy has been a dominant force politically and economically within the state.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AlmanacOil_181-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-AlmanacOil-181">\n         [179]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       If Texas were its own country it would be the sixth largest oil producer in the world.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182">\n        <a href="#cite_note-182">\n         [180]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The\n       <a href="/wiki/Railroad_Commission_of_Texas" title="Railroad Commission of Texas">\n        Railroad Commission of Texas\n       </a>\n       , contrary to its name, regulates the state\'s\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oil_industry" title="Oil industry">\n        oil and gas industry\n       </a>\n       , gas utilities, pipeline safety, safety in the\n       <a href="/wiki/Liquefied_petroleum_gas" title="Liquefied petroleum gas">\n        liquefied petroleum gas\n       </a>\n       industry, and surface coal and\n       <a href="/wiki/Uranium" title="Uranium">\n        uranium\n       </a>\n       mining. Until the 1970s, the commission controlled the price of petroleum because of its ability to regulate Texas\'s oil reserves. The founders of the\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organization_of_Petroleum_Exporting_Countries" title="Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries">\n        Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries\n       </a>\n       (OPEC) used the Texas agency as one of their models for petroleum price control.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RRcommission_183-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-RRcommission-183">\n         [181]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Texas has known petroleum deposits of about 5 billion barrels (790,000,000\xc2\xa0m\n       <sup>\n        3\n       </sup>\n       ), which makes up about one-fourth of the known U.S. reserves.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Petrol_184-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Petrol-184">\n         [182]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The state\'s\n       <a href="/wiki/Oil_refinery" title="Oil refinery">\n        refineries\n       </a>\n       can process 4.6 million barrels (730,000\xc2\xa0m\n       <sup>\n        3\n       </sup>\n       ) of oil a day.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Petrol_184-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Petrol-184">\n         [182]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The\n       <a href="/wiki/Baytown_Refinery" title="Baytown Refinery">\n        Baytown Refinery\n       </a>\n       in the Houston area is the largest refinery in America.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Petrol_184-2">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Petrol-184">\n         [182]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Texas also leads in natural gas production, producing one-fourth of the nation\'s supply.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Petrol_184-3">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Petrol-184">\n         [182]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Several\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_petroleum_companies" title="List of petroleum companies">\n        petroleum companies\n       </a>\n       are based in Texas such as:\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anadarko_Petroleum_Corporation" title="Anadarko Petroleum Corporation">\n        Anadarko Petroleum Corporation\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Conoco-Phillips" title="Conoco-Phillips">\n        Conoco-Phillips\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Exxon-Mobil" title="Exxon-Mobil">\n        Exxon-Mobil\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Halliburton" title="Halliburton">\n        Halliburton\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Marathon_Oil" title="Marathon Oil">\n        Marathon Oil\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tesoro" title="Tesoro">\n        Tesoro\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Valero_Energy_Corporation" title="Valero Energy Corporation">\n        Valero\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Western_Refining" title="Western Refining">\n        Western Refining\n       </a>\n       .\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       According to the\n       <a href="/wiki/Energy_Information_Administration" title="Energy Information Administration">\n        Energy Information Administration\n       </a>\n       , Texans consume, on average, the fifth most energy (of all types) in the nation per capita and as a whole, following behind Wyoming, Alaska, Louisiana, North Dakota, and Iowa.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Petrol_184-4">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Petrol-184">\n         [182]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Unlike the rest of the nation, most of Texas is on its own\n       <a href="/wiki/Alternating_current" title="Alternating current">\n        alternating current\n       </a>\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Power_grid" title="Power grid">\n        power grid\n       </a>\n       , the\n       <a href="/wiki/Texas_Interconnection" title="Texas Interconnection">\n        Texas Interconnection\n       </a>\n       . Texas has a\n       <a href="/wiki/Deregulation_of_the_Texas_electricity_market" title="Deregulation of the Texas electricity market">\n        deregulated\n       </a>\n       electric service. Texas leads the nation in total net electricity production, generating 437,236 MWh in 2014, 89% more MWh than Florida, which ranked second.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185">\n        <a href="#cite_note-185">\n         [183]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186">\n        <a href="#cite_note-186">\n         [184]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       As an independent nation, Texas would rank as the world\'s eleventh-\n       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_electricity_consumption" title="List of countries by electricity consumption">\n        largest producer of electricity\n       </a>\n       , after South Korea, and ahead of the United Kingdom.\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The state is a leader in\n       <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy_commercialization" title="Renewable energy commercialization">\n        renewable energy commercialization\n       </a>\n       ; it produces the most\n       <a href="/wiki/Wind_power_in_Texas" title="Wind power in Texas">\n        wind power\n       </a>\n       in the nation.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Petrol_184-5">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Petrol-184">\n         [182]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wind2_187-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-wind2-187">\n         [185]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       In 2014, 10.6% of the electricity consumed in Texas came from\n       <a href="/wiki/Wind_turbine" title="Wind turbine">\n        wind turbines\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188">\n        <a href="#cite_note-188">\n         [186]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The\n       <a href="/wiki/Roscoe_Wind_Farm" title="Roscoe Wind Farm">\n        Roscoe Wind Farm\n       </a>\n       in\n       <a href="/wiki/Roscoe,_Texas" title="Roscoe, Texas">\n        Roscoe, Texas\n       </a>\n       , is one of the world\'s largest\n       <a href="/wiki/Wind_farm" title="Wind farm">\n        wind farms\n       </a>\n       with a 781.5\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Megawatt" title="Megawatt">\n        megawatt\n       </a>\n       (MW) capacity.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RoscoeWind_189-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-RoscoeWind-189">\n         [187]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The Energy Information Administration states that the state\'s large agriculture and forestry industries could give Texas an enormous amount\n       <a href="/wiki/Biomass" title="Biomass">\n        biomass\n       </a>\n       for use in biofuels. The state also has the highest\n       <a href="/wiki/Solar_power" title="Solar power">\n        solar power\n       </a>\n       potential for development in the nation.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Petrol_184-6">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Petrol-184">\n         [182]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h3>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Technology">\n        Technology\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <p>\n       With large universities systems coupled with initiatives like the Texas Enterprise Fund and the\n       <a href="/wiki/Texas_Emerging_Technology_Fund" title="Texas Emerging Technology Fund">\n        Texas Emerging Technology Fund\n       </a>\n       , a wide array of different\n       <a href="/wiki/High_tech" title="High tech">\n        high tech\n       </a>\n       industries have developed in Texas. The Austin area is nicknamed the "Silicon Hills" and the north Dallas area the "\n       <a href="/wiki/Silicon_Prairie" title="Silicon Prairie">\n        Silicon Prairie\n       </a>\n       ". Texas has the headquarters of many high technology companies, such as\n       <a href="/wiki/Dell" title="Dell">\n        Dell\n       </a>\n       , Inc.,\n       <a href="/wiki/Texas_Instruments" title="Texas Instruments">\n        Texas Instruments\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Perot_Systems" title="Perot Systems">\n        Perot Systems\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Rackspace" title="Rackspace">\n        Rackspace\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/AT%26T" title="AT&amp;T">\n        AT&amp;T\n       </a>\n       .\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Aeronautics_and_Space_Administration" title="National Aeronautics and Space Administration">\n        National Aeronautics and Space Administration\n       </a>\n       \'s\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lyndon_B._Johnson_Space_Center" title="Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center">\n        Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center\n       </a>\n       (NASA JSC) located in Southeast Houston, sits as the crown jewel of Texas\'s aeronautics industry.\n       <a href="/wiki/Fort_Worth,_Texas" title="Fort Worth, Texas">\n        Fort Worth\n       </a>\n       hosts both\n       <a href="/wiki/Lockheed_Martin" title="Lockheed Martin">\n        Lockheed Martin\n       </a>\n       \'s\n       <a href="/wiki/Lockheed_Martin_Aeronautics" title="Lockheed Martin Aeronautics">\n        Aeronautics division\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bell_Helicopter_Textron" title="Bell Helicopter Textron">\n        Bell Helicopter Textron\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LM1_190-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-LM1-190">\n         [188]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bell_191-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Bell-191">\n         [189]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Lockheed builds the\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/F-16_Fighting_Falcon" title="F-16 Fighting Falcon">\n        F-16 Fighting Falcon\n       </a>\n       , the largest Western fighter program, and its successor, the\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/F-35_Lightning_II" title="F-35 Lightning II">\n        F-35 Lightning II\n       </a>\n       in Fort Worth.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Downside_192-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Downside-192">\n         [190]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h3>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Commerce">\n        Commerce\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <p>\n       Texas\'s\n       <a href="/wiki/Affluence_in_the_United_States" title="Affluence in the United States">\n        affluence\n       </a>\n       stimulates a strong commercial sector consisting of retail, wholesale, banking and insurance, and construction industries. Examples of Fortune 500 companies not based on Texas traditional industries are\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/AT%26T_Inc" title="AT&amp;T Inc">\n        AT&amp;T\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Kimberly-Clark" title="Kimberly-Clark">\n        Kimberly-Clark\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Blockbuster_Inc." title="Blockbuster Inc.">\n        Blockbuster\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/J._C._Penney" title="J. C. Penney">\n        J. C. Penney\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Whole_Foods_Market" title="Whole Foods Market">\n        Whole Foods Market\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Tenet_Healthcare" title="Tenet Healthcare">\n        Tenet Healthcare\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fortune500_2_193-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-fortune500_2-193">\n         [191]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Nationally, the Dallas\xe2\x80\x93Fort Worth area, home to the\n       <a href="/wiki/Highland_Park_Village" title="Highland Park Village">\n        second shopping mall\n       </a>\n       in the United States, has the most shopping malls per capita of any American metropolitan area.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VisitDallas_Shopping_194-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-VisitDallas_Shopping-194">\n         [192]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Mexico, the state\'s largest trading partner, imports a third of the state\'s exports because of the\n       <a href="/wiki/North_American_Free_Trade_Agreement" title="North American Free Trade Agreement">\n        North American Free Trade Agreement\n       </a>\n       (NAFTA). NAFTA has encouraged the formation of controversial\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maquiladoras" title="Maquiladoras">\n        maquiladoras\n       </a>\n       on the Texas/Mexico border.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-economy2_195-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-economy2-195">\n         [193]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h2>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">\n        Demographics\n       </span>\n      </h2>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Main article:\n       <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Texas" title="Demographics of Texas">\n        Demographics of Texas\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <table class="toccolours" style="border-spacing: 1px; float: right; clear: right; margin: 0 0 1em 1em; text-align:right">\n       <tr>\n        <th class="navbox-title" colspan="4" style="padding-right:3px; padding-left:3px; font-size:110%; text-align:center">\n      </th>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <td style="text-align:center">\n         <b>\n          <a href="/wiki/1850_United_States_Census" title="1850 United States Census">\n           1850\n    </td>\n        <td style="font-size:85%">\n        </td>\n        <td style="padding-left:8px; text-align: center;">\n         184.2%\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <td
